items.author: Joshua Rothkopf
items.content: Here's where it's easiest to see Clouzot's advantage over his more famous peer, as he combines nail-biting action scenes - calibrated to the millimeter - with a Hawksian command of earthy performances.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: The film's extended suspense sequences deserve a place among the great stretches of cinema.

items.author: James Berardinelli
items.content: Wages of Fear is the kind of motion picture for which commonplace phrases like "white-knuckle tension ride" have been coined.

items.author: Mike D'Angelo
items.content: Deriving endless anxiety from brawny men moving as gingerly as possible, it’s a riveting anti-action movie, one of the most memorable high-concept pictures ever made in Europe.

items.author: Rita Kempley
items.content: A precursor of The Wild Bunch, it is an expertly directed, personally felt film.

items.author: Kathleen Maher
items.content: This film, the inspiration for the less successful Sorcerer, is a textbook case of how to handle suspense. It has also been called the cruelest movie ever made and it certainly earns that title by the film's end.

items.author: Eric Henderson
items.content: Henri-Georges Clouzot’s The Wages of Fear now seems much less like Salt of the Earth-as-a-potboiler and a lot more like the spiritual godfather to every testosterone-fueled thrill ride since.

items.author: Bosley Crowther
items.content: The excitement derives entirely from the awareness of nitroglycerine and the gingerly, breathless handling of it. You sit there waiting for the theatre to explode.

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: A significant influence on Peckinpah's The Wild Bunch, this grueling pile driver of a movie will keep you on the edge of your seat, though it reeks of French 50s attitude, which includes misogyny, snobbishness, and borderline racism.
